Posts.Title: Mouth sores silentbell shaah2468

Posts.Content: shaah2468 wrote: I just wanted to post a special thank you to the hospital I have been under since my original diagnosis over 20 years ago now, the Royal Marsden Hospital in London.  I hope I am allowed to do this. When I returned with my second recurrance over 20 years later I was pleasantly surprised to see alot of the same staff and nurses still there and this gave me a feeling of reassurance.  They knew me well and I knew them and I felt a continuity, if that is the right word.  I have bonded with a few of them over the years and there is not a negative word I could say about any of the staff in that hospital.  They are caring, they listen, they are patient, they give you all the time you need from them, they pull strings to get you the right treatment, and they put up with my tantrums, what else could one want. I have just finished my dreaded first course of chemo and thanks to the nurses at the chemo unit they have made the experience alot more bearable than I thought it could be.  They always had a smile on their faces when they greeted me, they were gentle putting in canulas and administering chemo, they chatted away to distract from what was going on and helped to relax me.  There was also free sandwiches and snacks and drinks for anyone having chemo and tv/radio/internet screens by each chair.  And as awful as the ordeal of chemo was these little things all helped in small ways with me getting through my chemo days. I will probably be under the Royal Marsden now for the rest of my life and I honestly would not want to be in any other hands.  This is a terrible disease and ordeal for anyone to have to go through but I also like to look for the small blessings and help that come along the way and without which I could not make the journey.  All the best. Dx 11/15/2008 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A Thank You to My Hospital shaah2468 Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 01:18PM - edited Apr 25, 2012 01:19PM by shaah2468 I had two lumpectomies in same breast and both times it was fairly straightforward and felt ready to go home the next day.  Size wise there was only a slight difference in breast size but as I put on some weight over the years only the breast that was good at the time put on the weight but the one that had surgery and radiotherapy never did so I had noticeably different sizes until I lost the weight again.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - what can i expect? Shayne Angelaw69

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 12:40PM shaah2468 wrote: It is very encouraging to see some of you ladies with your new hair post chemo, you all look so great.  I had my final chemo treatment almost 3 weeks ago now and even before that I had some noticeable peach fuzz growing on my head.  It is very soft, not rough like stubble, and I like to feel it with my hands.  So it seems possible that hair can start to grow back even before finishing chemo.  My peach fuzz started to come in after my fifth treatment.  I was so worried it might not grow back so I feel relieved now.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: shaah2468 wrote: I finished my 6 courses of AC just over a month ago.  I am feeling more like myself now physically and all side effects have passed.  Even though I was having Neulasta shots I sitll developed a chest infection and fever and was in hospital for 3 days.  This was after my fifth dose of chemo.  So I guess Neulasta is not fool proof. All of the physical symptoms of my advanced bc in both breasts have gone and the breasts are soft and floppy again, good skin texture and mostly all the orange peel is gone, good color, swellings and lymphodema gone.  But two weeks ago I noticed something on the original breast.  Two years ago I developed what looks like a crease or seam on the breast starting at the nipple and going right to the end of the breast, very strange.  Even my doctor said she had never seen that before.  Now two weeks ago there is a bit of skin that looks bunched up right in the center of this seam and feels hard to the touch.  It is worrying me silly especially having just finished chemo.  It is oval, smooth, with round edges, almost little finger shaped.  The doctor says she is not overly concerned considering the cancer will likely not completely go anymore and I will just stay on treatments now.  She thinks it could be a deposit of some kind or something that was there before the chemo but could not be felt because of swelling and fluid.  The bottom half of that breast is virtually non existant now, having flattened against itself so much since the last recurrance.  You don't even need to feel this little "finger shaped" thing because you can see with the eye the bunched up skin.  I am having another ultrasound this week because not alot could be seen before chemo due to the oedema and thickening and also having a biopsy to the second breast.  Everytime I go to sleep I have bad dreams that either someone is telling me I am dying or I am telling someone I am dying and I see blood dripping down my legs and feet but for some reason I have 4 legs and 4 feet.  I am slowly going crazy. Dx 11/15/2008 Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 09:13AM shaah2468 wrote: When I had my first surgery and they yanked out the drains it was one of the worse pains I ever felt and I screamed for several minutes afterward.  After my second surgery I refused to let them remove my drains until they gave me a painkiller.  They put a mask on my face and told me to breathe in what I assume was oxygen for a few minutes and when they pulled out the drain I did not feel a thing.
Posts.Title: Drain removal with no pain meds?! Stormynyte SerendipiTea

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 04:11PM shaah2468 wrote: Being a Muslim I am used to wearing my beautiful headscarves and have considered a wig just for wearing at home.  Recently a lady at my hospital who is adapting to headscarves during chemo asked me how we keep them from slipping around and I told her about bonnets that are worn under our scarves. They are little caps and some of them tie at the back. They are also good for sleeping in if one's bare head gets cold at night because the cotton ones are so soft and comfortable.  I have loads of bonnets in different colors and contrast them with my headscarves at the front.  I get them online for very cheap, 99 pence UK money.  And not to forget gorgeous headscarves make a statement whether it be religious or fashion.
Posts.Title: What was your favorite head covering through chemo? BooBee Brendatrue
